page.title: 12DEANS PLACE HOTEL, ALFRISTON
page.content: This hotel situated at the southern end of Alfriston adjoins the Tye and Clergy House, with the Cuckmere meandering nearby. The site is old, first being documented as 'Dene' in Tudor times, and was probably associated with John de Dene of Alfricchestone in 1355. Evidence exists that it was moated, and may have had manor status, it being the only site in Alfriston permitted a dovecote. In 1866 a 'pest house' was situated at Deans Place 'Farm', probably an outbuilding serving as an isolation hospital. During the 1914-18 War it was called 'Hydro', and following the 1939-45 War it was much extended to become a busy hotel. Today under Michael and Janet Pritchard it has 44 bedrooms with private bathrooms together with conference facilities and attracts many walkers as guests.
